english: to overcome; gram; to restrain; be able to

etymology.type: ideogrammic compound (會意); alternatively pictogram (象形)
etymology.description: 會意: 由 (battle helmet) + 皮 (pelt) → ‘to defeat/vanquish’; alternatively 象形: 卩 (person) carrying 由 (a load) → ‘to shoulder/be competent’.
etymology.interpretation: One analysis sees a helmet and a pelt evoking triumph in combat, hence senses like overcoming or subduing. Another views a person bearing a load, extending to being able, managing, or having capacity. Later usages broadened to restraint and the metric unit reading.
etymology.simplification: Traditional 剋 was simplified by dropping the right-side 刂, merging into the long-used form 克 to reduce strokes while keeping pronunciation and core senses.

examples.chinese: 我们必须克服困难(我們必須克服困難)。
他很能克制自己(他很能克制自己)。
这块糖重五克(這塊糖重五克)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè kuài táng zhòng wǔ kè.
examples.english: This piece of candy weighs five grams.
